title: OmicSelector: Deep learning tutorial.
text: One important functionalities OmicSelector ability develop deep learning models. OmicSelector focuses biomarker feature selection model development, one solutions developing deep feedforward neural networks (3 hidden layers) without (sparse) autoencoder. OmicSelector provides framework graphical interface develop best artificial neural network molecular, laboratory, clinical data. Please note, however, OmicSelector designed handle images DICOM files. Multiple alternatives exist handle imaging data. solution’s primary purpose develop best classification tool limited number samples available (e.g., expression data; due cost). researcher like create classifier resilient overfitting. extensions provides unified pipeline utilizes TensorFlow though Keras create feedforward neural networks. OmicSelector, however, doesn’t require knowledge technologies. extension needs loaded using: function loads latest version extension GitHub: https://github.com/kstawiski/OmicSelector/blob/master/extensions/deeplearning.R
code: OmicSelector::OmicSelector_load_extension("deeplearning")

title: OmicSelector: Deep learning tutorial.
text: extension requires three datasets: training, testing, validation datasets, Benchmarking (standard OmicSelector pipeline). can prepared using OmicSelector_prepare_split() designed manually. primary function training neural networks called OmicSelector_deep_learning(). function aims train several neural networks, test performance, save models, provide general overview whole modeling. OmicSelector_deep_learning() defined following parameters: General setup parameters: selected_miRNAs - character vector features interest (selected features). function subset train networks features. wd - working directory data files found. working directory function expects: mixed_train.csv (training set), mixed_test.csv (testing set), mixed_valid.csv (validation set). files contain binary Class variables (values Case Control) features interest (starting prefix hsa). SMOTE - logical parameter defining balanced training set used analysis. set FALSE, function use mixed_train.csv training set without modification. set TRUE balanced dataset used. Balancing based OmicSelector_load_datamix() function. clean_temp_files - logical parameter defining temporary files (directory temp-deeplearning) deleted function finishes. best neural networks saved separate models directory, advise keeping TRUE. Setting FALSE may useful debugging. Saving options: save_threshold_trainacc - threshold training accuracy required model considered worth saving. Suppose set 0.85, models training accuracy < 0.85 regarded worthless disregarded. save_threshold_testacc - threshold testing accuracy required model considered worth saving. Suppose set 0.85, models testing accuracy < 0.85 regarded worthless disregarded. add_features_to_predictions - logical parameter features added predictions model files. network trained, function checks performance using network predictions 3 (training, testing, validation) datasets. may useful analysis, increase final model zip files’ size. care storage space, set FALSE. output_file - name csv file used save results (hyperparameters performance) training process. Without extension (.e. .csv) also defines name configuration. training accuracy > save_threshold_trainacc testing accuracy > save_threshold_testacc required consider model useful. save storage space save working models. Please note, however, metrics models saved output_file analysis. Training control parameters: keras_batch_size - Batch size number training examples one pass. higher batch size, memory space ’ll need. keras_epochae - Maximum number epoch (one forward pass one backward pass training examples) process autoencoder training. keras_epoch - Maximum number epoch (one forward pass one backward pass training examples) process final feedforward network training. keras_patience - many epochs improvement validation loss (loss testing set) training stopped? See keras::callback_early_stopping() details. keras_threads - function allows make training process parallel different sets hyperparameters. Depending hardware (CPU/GPU, memory, HDD/SDD speed etc.) dataset size, choose individually. value 2 always safe, mean two networks trained time presets, may take eternity finish process. OmicSelector trains defined number epochs (assuming early stopping criteria met), final network one lowest validation loss. Hyperparameters (grid search): Hyperparameters data frame contains information hyperparameter sets want check grid search best model. can play following hyperparameters: layer1 - number neurons first hidden layer layer2 - number neurons second hidden layer. set 0 = none. layer3 - number neurons third hidden layer. set 0 = none. activation_function_layer1 - activation function used first hidden layer. Use names : https://keras.io/api/layers/activations/ activation_function_layer2 - activation function used second hidden layer. Use names : https://keras.io/api/layers/activations/ activation_function_layer3 - activation function used third hidden layer. Use names : https://keras.io/api/layers/activations/ dropout_layer1 - dropout rate first hidden layer. Dropout layer randomly sets input units 0 frequency rate step training time, helps prevent overfitting. dropout_layer2 - dropout rate second hidden layer. dropout_layer3 - dropout rate third hidden layer. layer1_regularizer - regularization used first hidden layer. use L1 regularization L1 regularization penalty 0.001. Regularizers allow apply penalties layer parameters layer activity optimization. layer2_regularizer - regularization used second hidden layer. layer3_regularizer - regularization used third hidden layer. optimizer - use one available optimizers (https://keras.io/api/optimizers/). recommend adam. autoencoder - many neurons autoencoder used structure network. set 0 - autoencoder used, meaning training features go input layer directly. set >0, e.g. 4, 5-layer autoencoder created deep features autoencoder used training feedforward neural networks. scenario, second hidden layer maximum 7 neurons. following bottleneck layer (deep features) number neurons equal autoencoder parameter (4 example). set <0, e.g. -4 similar autoencoder created L1 regulization (L1 regularization penalty 0.001) used hidden layers - creating sparse autoencoder. Autoencoders inherit training parameters (e.g., optimizer; first layer hyperparameter set). balanced - balanced training set used. formula - formulas. advise create using .character(OmicSelector_create_formula(selected_miRNAs))[3]. scaled - z-score applied datasets modeling. Scaling can speed improve process training. Scaling parameters calculated training set reapplied testing validation sets. want check hyperparameter sets (rows hyperparameters dataset): start - row hyperparameters data frame start? end - row hyperparameters data frame end? can use default values don’t know . OmicSelector’s GUI uses default values set us. OmicSelector’s GUI use 3 presets hyperparameters: Quick scan (simple neural networks = 1 hidden layer without autoencoders; 1994 networks): Full scan (feedforward neural networks 3 hidden layers, without autoencoders; 97848 networks): Extended scan (feedforward neural networks 3 hidden layers, without autoencoders, autoencoders sparse autoencoders; 293544 networks)

save_threshold_testacc = 0.8,                                       keras_epochae = 5000,                                       keras_epoch = 2000,                                       keras_patience = 50,                                       hyperparameters = expand.grid(                                         layer1 = seq(3, 11, by = 2),                                         layer2 = c(0, title: OmicSelector: Deep learning tutorial.
text: network’s standard training regulated structure (defined current hyperparameters). data frame hyperparameters defines hyperparameter sets checked training process. grid search, every set hyperparameters fit process. function starts looking current working directory data (defined wd). expects files named mixed_train.csv (training set), mixed_test.csv (testing set), mixed_valid.csv (validation set). file contain binary Class variable (values Case Control) features interest (starting prefix hsa). Neural networks trained early stopping. neural network trained based ROC analysis, cutoff chosen. use cutoff maximum value Youden index (Youden’s J statistic = sensitivity + specificity - 1). predicted probability greater equal cutoff, case predicted Case. Otherwise, considered Control. Let’s create files TCGA data. Let’s train just 5 neural networks 1 hidden layer (sake quick tutorial): Deep learning results also saved deeplearning_results.csv. file contains following variables: Hyperparameters (defined descibed ): layer1, layer2, layer3, activation_function_layer1, activation_function_layer2, activation_function_layer3, dropout_layer1, dropout_layer2, dropout_layer3, layer1_regularizer, layer2_regularizer, layer3_regularizer, optimizer, autoencoder, balanced, formula, scaled model_id - model ID reference training_AUC - area ROC curve training process. cutoff - threshold predicted probability predicting Case (vs. Control). predicted probability >= cutoff, Case. training_AUC2 - training_AUC, calculated using different package (sanity check). training_AUC_lower95CI - lower 95%CI AUC ROC training_AUC_upper95CI - upper 95%CI AUC ROC training_Accuracy - accuracy training set training_Sensitivity - sensitivity training set (Case class interest) training_Specificity - specificity training set training_PPV - positive predictive value training set training_NPV - negative predicitve value training set training_F1 - F1-measure training set test_Accuracy - accuracy testing set test_Sensitivity - sensitivity testing set test_Specificity - specificity testing set test_PPV - PPV testing set test_NPV - NPV testing set test_F1 - F1-measure testing set valid_Accuracy - accuracy validation set valid_Sensitivity - sensitivity validation set valid_Specificity - specificity validation set valid_PPV - PPV validation set valid_NPV - NPV validation set valid_F1 - F1-measure validation set name - name model (including configuration name), add .zip suffix represent model filename models/ directory. worth_saving - worth_saving (.e. saved models/ directory) performance low disregarded training_time - training time model seconds. [Please note parallel training may incorrect.] prefer choose best model based highest metaindex value. Metaindex average accuracy metrics (training, testing, validation sets), final decision arbitrary.
code: data("orginal_TCGA_data") suppressWarnings(suppressMessages(library(dplyr))) cancer_cases = filter(orginal_TCGA_data, primary_site == "Pancreas" & sample_type == "PrimaryTumor") control_cases = filter(orginal_TCGA_data, sample_type == "SolidTissueNormal") cancer_cases$Class = "Case" control_cases$Class = "Control" dataset = rbind(cancer_cases, control_cases) ttpm = OmicSelector_counts_to_log10tpm(danex = dplyr::select(dataset, starts_with("hsa")), metadane = dplyr::select(dataset, -starts_with("hsa")), ids = dataset$sample,     filtr = F, filtr_minimalcounts = 1, filtr_howmany = 0.01) #>  #> DGEList unfiltered object with TPM was saved as TPM_DGEList.rds. #> Returned data are log10(TPM). ttpm = as.data.frame(ttpm) zero_var = which(apply(ttpm, 2, var) == 0)  #which have no variance ttpm = ttpm[, -zero_var] # Not run: DE = OmicSelector_differential_expression_ttest(ttpm_features = dplyr::select(dataset, starts_with('hsa')), classes = dataset$Class, mode # = 'logtpm') significant = DE$miR[DE$`p-value Bonferroni`<0.05] selected_miRNAs = make.names(c("hsa-miR-192-5p", "hsa-let-7g-5p", "hsa-let-7a-5p", "hsa-miR-194-5p", "hsa-miR-122-5p", "hsa-miR-340-5p", "hsa-miR-26b-5p"))  # some selected miRNAs match(selected_miRNAs, colnames(ttpm)) #> [1]  87 167   1 251 180 337  43 # dataset = dataset[sample(1:nrow(dataset),200),] # sample 100 random cases to make it quicker OmicSelector_table(table(dataset$Class), col.names = c("Class", "Number of cases")) #>  #>    Case Control  #>     178     675 # For full analysis: merged = OmicSelector_prepare_split(metadane = dplyr::select(dataset, -starts_with('hsa')), ttpm = ttpm)  merged = OmicSelector_prepare_split(metadane = dplyr::select(dataset, -starts_with("hsa")), ttpm = dplyr::select(ttpm, selected_miRNAs)) #>  #> Saved 3 sets as csv in working directory. Retruned mixed dataset. knitr::kable(table(merged$Class, merged$mix)) SMOTE = F  # use unbalanced set deep_learning_results = OmicSelector_deep_learning(selected_miRNAs = selected_miRNAs, start = 5, end = 10)  # use default set of hyperparameters and options DT::datatable(deep_learning_results, extensions = c("FixedColumns", "FixedHeader"), options = list(scrollX = TRUE, paging = FALSE, fixedHeader = TRUE))

title: OmicSelector: Deep learning tutorial.
text: Deep neural networks created using OmicSelector can used prediction new datasets using: Input parameters: model_path - path zip file networking created using OmicSelector new_dataset - data frame new data, must contain variables names predictors new_scaling - network scaled using z-score (preprocessing), function can restore scaling parameters training process (recommended) create new scaling (useful dealing e.g. batch effect) old_train_csv_to_restore_scaling - default NULL; scaling parameters saved model, sometimes may want modify . want calculate scaling parameters based dataset, please provide path csv file. override_cutoff - default predictions made based predicted probability cutoff (highest Youden index training process; remains constant sets); want , can give cutoff blinded - dataset contains Class variable, can set TRUE, performance automatically calculated Output (list): predictions - data frame predicted probabilites classes network_config - data frame network configuration new_dataset - data frame new dataset predictions (preprocessing) new_dataset_x - data frame new dataset predictions preprocessing (scaling, deep features etc.) network_features - features (variables, predictiors) network cutoff - cutoff predicted probability used prediction col_mean_train - scaled network, mean values every variable col_sd_train - scaled network, standard deviation values every variable confusion_matrix - confusion matrix (performance assessment) roc - ROC curve (pROC object; can used plotting) roc_auc - AUC ROC model - model object (keras object) autoencoder - autoencoder model object (keras object) can see function working scoring tool inside OmicSelector’s GUI. interested code, look .
code: OmicSelector_deep_learning_predict = function(model_path = "our_models/model5.zip",                                               new_dataset = data.table::fread("Data/ks_data.csv"),                                               new_scaling = F,                                               old_train_csv_to_restore_scaling = NULL,                                               override_cutoff = NULL,                                               blinded = F)

packageDescription("OmicSelector") #> Package: OmicSelector #> Type: Package #> Title: OmicSelector - a package for biomarker selection based on #>        high-throughput experiments. #> Version: 1.0.0 #> Author: Konrad Stawiski #> Maintainer: Konrad Stawiski <konrad.stawiski@umed.lodz.pl> #> Description: OmicSelector is package is the environment, #>        docker-based application and R package for biomarker #>        signature selection from high-throughput experiments. #>        Initially developed for miRNA-seq. The package introduces #>        automatic and structured feature selection with further #>        benchmarking using multiple data mining methods, thus #>        allow to find the most overfitting resiliant signature #>        (set of featrues) that can be used in biomarker validation #>        studies. E.g. this package can be used to find the set of #>        miRNAs with the greatest biomarker potential based on #>        miRNAs-seq. This set can be further validated in cheaper #>        qPCR studies. #> License: License: MIT + file LICENSE #> Encoding: UTF-8 #> LazyData: true #> Suggests: knitr, rmarkdown #> VignetteBuilder: title: OmicSelector: Basic Functionality Tutorial.
text: present package functionality, use pan-cancer data TCGA (https://portal.gdc.cancer.gov/repository). two commands download store data required working directory. Please note process may take time (depending network connection), performed . functions produce two files: tissue_miRNA_counts.csv tissue_miRNA_logtpm.csv. first file contains metadata raw counts declared TCGA. second log-transformed transcripts-per-million (TPM) counts. Let’s load counts files see summary. Let’s consider following exemplary problem. want find set miRNAs specific pancreatic cancer. see 178 cases pancreatic cancer miRNA-seq results four solid tissue normal cases ur TCGA dataset. However, multiple normal tissue miRNA-seq results projects incorporate analysis. Let’s filter label samples interest. pipeline requires variable Class two levels (Case Control) present dataset.  statistically significant difference age classes. Gender associated class. increase feature selection performance, try balance sets performing propensity score matching. Let’s check imbalance new, transformed dataset.  significant differences age gender composition classes now. can proceed standard filtering, log-transformation, TPM-normalization. However, first, stay consistent different datasets, need standardize microRNA names. OmicSelector_correct_miRNA_names() unify miRNA names different versions miRbase. might noticed filtered microRNAs least 100 counts 1/3 samples. ensure microRNAs selected features classifier (possibly useful clinic) detectable , cheaper methods, qPCR. filtering, 166 miRNAs left. next step, divide dataset training, testing, validation datasets. strongly believe hold-validation redundant validation method, although OmicSelector supports cross-validation, hold-confirmation set default cases. Thus, rest analysis dependent existence 3 separate datasets: Training dataset (mixed_train.csv): default 60%, used differential expression, feature selection model training. Testing dataset (mixed_test.csv): default 20%, used hyperparameter selection (holdout=T mode) performance assessment. Validation dataset (mixed_valid.csv): default 20%, used performance assessment. best signature (best set miRNAs diagnostic test) can selected based three datasets, two datasets, validation set. discuss process best signature selection . split can prepared manually user (pipeline expects find mixed_*.csv files working directory) convenient way using OmicSelector_prepare_split(). Let’s now. Let’s see split summary. can see dataset divided balanced way. Now ready move analysis…

Rectosigmoid junction|Colon junction|Unknown|Rectum|Colon|Connective, subcutaneous and other soft tissues suppressWarnings(suppressMessages(library(dplyr)))  cancer_cases = filter(orginal_TCGA_data, primary_site == "Pancreas" & sample_type == "PrimaryTumor") control_cases = filter(orginal_TCGA_data, sample_type == "SolidTissueNormal") cancer_cases$Class = "Case" control_cases$Class = "Control"  dataset = rbind(cancer_cases, control_cases)  OmicSelector_table(table(dataset$Class), col.names = c("Class", "Number of cases")) #>  #>    Case Control  #>     178     675 boxplot(dataset$age_at_diagnosis ~ dataset$Class) t.test(dataset$age_at_diagnosis ~ dataset$Class) #>  #>  Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  dataset$age_at_diagnosis by dataset$Class #> t = 3.88, df = 360.55, p-value = 0.0001242 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group Case and group Control is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>   693.0905 2117.7294 #> sample estimates: #>    mean in group Case mean in group Control  #>              23782.23              22376.82 OmicSelector_table(table(dataset$gender.x, dataset$Class)) #>          #>          Case Control #>   female   80     334 #>   male     98     325 chisq.test(dataset$gender.x, dataset$Class) #>  #>  Pearson's Chi-squared test with Yates' continuity correction #>  #> data:  dataset$gender.x and dataset$Class #> X-squared = 1.6241, df = 1, p-value = 0.2025 old_dataset = dataset  # backup dataset = dataset[grepl("Adenocarcinomas", dataset$disease_type), ] match_by = c("age_at_diagnosis", "gender.x") tempdane = dplyr::select(dataset, all_of(match_by)) tempdane$Class = ifelse(dataset$Class == "Case", TRUE, FALSE) suppressMessages(library(mice)) suppressMessages(library(MatchIt)) temp1 = mice(tempdane, m = 1) #>  #>  iter imp variable #>   1   1  age_at_diagnosis #>   2   1  age_at_diagnosis #>   3   1  age_at_diagnosis #>   4   1  age_at_diagnosis #>   5   1  age_at_diagnosis temp2 = temp1$data temp3 = mice::complete(temp1) temp3 = temp3[complete.cases(temp3), ] tempform = OmicSelector_create_formula(match_by) mod_match <- matchit(tempform, data = temp3) newdata = match.data(mod_match) dataset = dataset[as.numeric(rownames(newdata)), ] boxplot(dataset$age_at_diagnosis ~ dataset$Class) t.test(dataset$age_at_diagnosis ~ dataset$Class) #>  #>  Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  dataset$age_at_diagnosis by dataset$Class #> t = -0.088413, df = 351.73, p-value = 0.9296 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group Case and group Control is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -905.7633  827.8307 #> sample estimates: #>    mean in group Case mean in group Control  #>              23782.23              23821.20 OmicSelector_table(table(dataset$gender.x, dataset$Class)) #>          #>          Case Control #>   female   80      82 #>   male     98      96 chisq.test(dataset$gender.x, dataset$Class) #>  #>  Pearson's Chi-squared test with Yates' continuity correction #>  #> data:  dataset$gender.x and dataset$Class #> X-squared = 0.011327, df = 1, p-value = 0.9152 fwrite(dataset, "balanced_dataset.csv.gz") OmicSelector_tutorial_balanced_dataset = dataset  # can be used by data('OmicSelector_tutorial_balanced_dataset') # In real file use: (we won't run this in this tutorial) dataset = OmicSelector_correct_miRNA_names(dataset) This will correct miRNA names based on # the aliases. Useful when analyzing old datasets - to keep the results coherent with current knowledge.  danex = dplyr::select(dataset, starts_with("hsa"))  # Create data.frame or matrix with miRNA counts with miRNAs in columns and cases in rows. metadane = dplyr::select(dataset, -starts_with("hsa"))  # Metadata with 'Class' variables. OmicSelector_table(table(metadane$Class))  # Let's be sure that 'Class' variable is correct and contains only 'Case' and 'Control' cases. #>  #>    Case Control  #>     178     178 ttpm = OmicSelector_counts_to_log10tpm(danex, metadane, ids = metadane$sample, filtr = T, filtr_minimalcounts = 100, filtr_howmany = 1/3)  # We will leave only the miRNAs which apeared with at least 100 counts in 1/3 of cases. #>  #> DGEList unfiltered object with TPM was saved as TPM_DGEList.rds. #> DGEList filtered object with TPM was saved as TPM_DGEList_filtered.rds. #> (After filtering) miRNAs left: 166 | filtered out: 2418. #> Returned data are log10(TPM). mixed = OmicSelector_prepare_split(metadane = metadane, ttpm = ttpm, train_proc = 0.6) #>  #> Saved 3 sets as csv in working directory. Retruned mixed dataset. OmicSelector_tutorial_balanced_mixed = mixed  # can be used by data('OmicSelector_tutorial_balanced_mixed') mixed = fread("mixed.csv") OmicSelector_table(table(mixed$Class, mixed$mix)) #>           #>           test train valid #>   Case      36   107    35 #>   Control   36   107    35 OmicSelector_table(cbind(mixed[1:10, c(100:105)], Class = mixed[1:10, "Class"])) #>     hsa.miR.30c.5p hsa.miR.30c.2.3p hsa.miR.30d.5p hsa.miR.139.5p #>  1:       2.598949         1.514444       3.802908       1.555401 #>  2:       2.391663         1.416540       3.656058       1.326116 #>  3:       2.576255         1.566166       3.721311       1.220338 #>  4:       2.260491         1.401010       3.539243       1.924365 #>  5:       2.595315         1.562735       3.571441       1.721510 #>  6:       2.632860         1.723000       3.708021       2.120359 #>  7:       2.747742         2.016887       3.852090       1.533525 #>  8:       3.037578         1.880192       3.960987       1.798007 #>  9:       2.598933         1.291485       3.581714       1.413095 #> 10:       2.829601         1.494520       3.589292       1.755581 #>     hsa.miR.10a.5p hsa.miR.10b.5p Class.Class #>  1:       4.735516       4.298381        Case #>  2:       4.615369       3.946954        Case #>  3:       4.385001       3.998914        Case #>  4:       3.945605       4.486228        Case #>  5:       4.519249       4.126032        Case #>  6:       4.875796       3.887056        Case #>  7:       3.961177       3.642831        Case #>  8:       4.675070       4.133894        Case #>  9:       4.580566       3.960672        Case #> 10:       4.687104       4.209582        Case

title: OmicSelector: Basic Functionality Tutorial.
text: biomarker studies, rely validation. perform hold-verification, signature selection based training dataset . Including testing validation dataset exploratory analysis lead bias (‘data leakage’). following section, show use package perform quick exploratory analysis miRNA-seq data. OmicSelector_load_datamix() function loads data created preparation phase. requires output constructed OmicSelector_prepare_split() function placed working directory (‘wd’), thus files ‘mixed_train.csv’, ‘mixed_test.csv’ ‘mixed_valid.csv’ exist directory. split data manually, may imbalance classes train, test, validation datasets. , OmicSelector_prepare_split() perform balancing using: ROSE: https://journal.r-project.org/archive/2014/RJ-2014-008/RJ-2014-008.pdf - default, generate 10 * number cases original dataset. SMOTE (default): https://arxiv.org/abs/1106.1813 - default, use modification SMOTE, .e. add SMOTEd cases minority class (-/sample majority class). minimal amount added rows calculated compensate imbalance problem. See details code OmicSelector_load_datamix(). beginning analysis, usually perform principal component analysis (PCA) assess batch effect possible outliers; hence understand miRNA profile. package can construct 2-dimensional biplot 3-dimensional interactive scatterplot based computed components.  3D PCA plot may shown correctly Jupyter notebook, can check , e.g., R Studio. Now can also correct batch effect . example, can use OmicSelector_combat() . However, detailed demonstration scope tutorial. Usually, next step exploratory analysis perform differential expression analysis. Differential expression package biomarker-discovery oriented. Thus uses t-test correction multiple comparisons. following table shows significantly differently expressed miRNAs Benjamini-Hochberg correction. Let’s visualize results differential expression using heatmap volcano plot.  Z-scoring values clustering plotting help us gain insight.  also create vulcano plot label top 10 significant miRNAs:  may also check consistency differential expression datasets:

title: OmicSelector: Basic Functionality Tutorial.
text: package’s main feature shotgun-like feature selection evaluation possible miRNA signatures biological processes. can straightforwardly apply function, e.g.: , larger projects, suggest using following wrapper, perform feature selection parallel, significantly reducing computational time. recommend using five threads, methods inherently use multicore processing: using environment learn package, can tweak run code interactive notebook. Click . notes : function iterates available methods, described m parameter. function aims perform feature selection using multiple approaches create formulas benchmarking. loads data working directory. output mainly put files working directory. Log temporary files placed created temp subfolder. Files created method (e.g. stamp=tutorial m=1): formulastutorial-1.RDS - main result file containing final formula (final set miRNAs selected method). time1-formula.RDS - time taken compute results tutorial1featureselection.log - log file process (optional) all1-tutorial.rdata - variables created feature selection (created debug=T). Pearls methods: Sig = miRNAs p-value <0.05 BH correction (DE using t-test) Fcsig = sig + absolute log2FC filter (included abs. log2FC>1) Cfs = Correlation-based Feature Selection Machine Learning (: https://www.cs.waikato.ac.nz/~mhall/thesis.pdf) Classloop = Classification using different classification algorithms (classifiers) embedded feature selection using various schemes performance validation (: https://rdrr.io/cran/Biocomb/man/classifier.loop.html) Fcfs = CFS algorithm forward search (https://rdrr.io/cran/Biocomb/man/select.forward.Corr.html) MDL methods = minimal description length (MDL) discretization algorithm different method feature ranking feature selection (AUC, SU, CorrSF) (: https://rdrr.io/cran/Biocomb/man/select.process.html) bounceR = genetic algorithm componentwise boosting (: https://www.statworx.com/ch/blog/automated-feature-selection-using-bouncer/) RandomForestRFE = recursive feature elimination using random forest resampling assess performance. (: https://topepo.github.io/caret/recursive-feature-elimination.html#resampling--external-validation) GeneticAlgorithmRF (: https://topepo.github.io/caret/feature-selection-using-genetic-algorithms.html) SimulatedAnnealing = makes small random changes (.e. perturbations) initial candidate solution (: https://topepo.github.io/caret/feature-selection-using-simulated-annealing.html) Boruta (: https://www.jstatsoft.org/article/view/v036i11/v36i11.pdf) spFSR = simultaneous perturbation stochastic approximation (SPSA-FSR) (: https://arxiv.org/abs/1804.05589) varSelRF = using --bag error minimization criterion, carry variable elimination random forest successfully eliminating least important variables (importance returned random forest). (: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16398926) WxNet = neural network-based feature selection algorithm transcriptomic data (: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6642261/) Step = backward stepwise method feature selection based logistic regression (GLM, family = binomial) using AIC criteria (stepAIC) functions .stepwise package (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/.stepwise/index.html) Notes methods: OmicSelector functions saves output files temp/ directory. users may want run multiple selection methods different configurations, recommend using return function following steps. Instead, provide OmicSelector_merge_formulas() conviniently summerizes results feature selection. can : Note : Two files created working directory: (1) featureselection_formulas_all.RDS - contains formulas selection methods, (2) featureselection_formulas_final.RDS - contains methods selected smaller equal number microRNAs specified max_miRNA parameter, well fcsig cfs_sig. results fcsig cfs_sig methods always retained final formulas set (ignoring max_miRNA parameter) - commonly used benchmark comparator final set miRNAs. sets can manually removed (needed) final selection. Readable tables written corresponding *.csv files. Let’s analyze process feature selection: Note my_own_signture 0 miRNAs according table. trick ensures filter signatures added manually based max_miRNA parameter. summarize number microRNAs selected methods implemented OmicSelector_OmicSelector creating histogram calculating descriptive statistics.
code: library(OmicSelector) selected_features = OmicSelector_OmicSelector(wd = getwd(), m = c(1:4), max_iterations = 1, stamp = "tutorial")  # For the sake of this tutorial and vignette building we will use only few fastest methods. The m parameter defines what methods will be tested. See more details below. readLines("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kstawiski/OmicSelector/master/vignettes/Tutorial_OmicSelector.R") %>%     paste0(collapse = "\n") %>%     cat #> #options(warn = -1) #> library(OmicSelector) #> m = 1:56 # which methods to check? #>  #>  #> # RECOMMENDED: #> for (i in m) { #> OmicSelector_OmicSelector(m = i, max_iterations = 1, stamp = "fs", debug = F, # we set debug to false (to make the package smaller), you may also want to change stamp to something meaningful, max_iterations was set to 1 to recude the computational time.. in real life scenarios it is resonable to use at least 10 iterations. #>                   prefer_no_features = 11, # Few methods are filter rather than wrapper methods, thus requires the maximum number of maximum features.     #>                   timeout_sec = 600) # We don't want to wait eternity in this tutorial, just 10 minutes. Timeout is useful for complicated methods. Depending on your CPU 2 days may be reasonable for larger projects. Note that some methods cannot be controled with timeout parameter. #> } #>  #> # NOT RECOMMENDED: (due to huge computational load of some feature selection methods we do not recommend to run it in parallel, but it is possible) #> suppressMessages(library(foreach)) #> suppressMessages(library(doParallel)) #> suppressMessages(library(parallel)) #> suppressMessages(library(doParallel)) #> cl <- makePSOCKcluster(useXDR = TRUE, 5) # We do not recommend using more than 5 threads, beacuse some of the methods inhereditly use multicore processing. #>  registerDoParallel(cl) #> # on.exit(stopCluster(cl)) #> iterations = length(m) #> pb <- txtProgressBar(max = iterations, style = 3) #> progress <- function(n) setTxtProgressBar(pb, n) #> opts <- list(progress = progress) #> foreach(i = m, .options.snow = opts) %dopar% #> { #>   suppressMessages(library(OmicSelector)) #>   # setwd("/OmicSelector/OmicSelector/vignettes") # change it you to your working directory #>   OmicSelector_OmicSelector(m = i, max_iterations = 1, stamp = "tutorial", debug = F, # we set debug to false (to make the package smaller), you may also want to change stamp to something meaningful, max_iterations was set to 1 to recude the computational time.. in real life scenarios it is resonable to use at least 10 iterations. #>                   prefer_no_features = 11, # Few methods are filter rather than wrapper methods, thus requires the maximum number of maximum features. #>                   conda_path = "/opt/conda/bin/conda", # Methods line WxNet requires usage of python. In setup script we create conda enviorment. Providing conda_path makes it easier to activate env. We prefer this apporach over use_condaenv. #>                   timeout = 600) # We don't want to wait eternity in this tutorial, just 10 minutes. Timeout is useful for complicated methods. Depending on your CPU 2 days may be reasonable for larger projects. Note that some methods cannot be controled with timeout parameter. #> } #> stopCluster(cl) shiny::includeHTML("methods.html") selected_sets_of_miRNAs = OmicSelector_merge_formulas(max_miRNAs = 11)  # we filter out sets with more than 11 miRNAs. selected_sets_of_miRNAs_with_own = OmicSelector_merge_formulas(max_miRNAs = 11, add = list(my_own_signature = c("hsa.miR.192.5p", "hsa.let.7g.5p", "hsa.let.7a.5p",     "hsa.let.7d.5p", "hsa.miR.194.5p", "hsa.miR.98.5p", "hsa.let.7f.5p", "hsa.miR.26b.5p")))  # you can also add your own signature (for example selected from literature) all_sets = readRDS("featureselection_formulas_all.RDS") length(all_sets)  # How many feature selection methods completed in time? #> [1] 17 final_sets = readRDS("featureselection_formulas_final.RDS") length(final_sets)  # How many feature selection methods completed in time and fulfilled max_miRNA criteria? (remember about fcsig and cfs_sig) #> [1] 6 featureselection_formulas_final = fread("featureselection_formulas_final.csv") OmicSelector_table(featureselection_formulas_final)  # show information about title: OmicSelector: Basic Functionality Tutorial.
text: next step looking best microRNA signature, perform benchmarking. tests signatures using different classifier architectures. example benchmark default parameters: using environment learn package, can tweak run code interactive notebook. Click . Just rendering tutorial, use straightforward benchmark using logistic regression conditional trees. benchmarking done, main result file saved file specified output_file parameter. contains performance metrics signatures satisfying initial criteria (e.g. max_miRNA) across different methods modeling. Let’s take quick look: Description columns: method - accronym method SMOTE - balancing using SMOTE ROSE used training dataset. miRy - formula used (miRNAs selected). *_modelname - name .RDS file placed models/ directory, containing caret final model can used prediction new cases. allows reproducibility results. example glm_ prefix set according method, glm = logistic regression. *_train_ROCAUC - area ROC curve (AUC ROC) training dataset, indicating general potential model. *_train_ROCAUC_lower95CI - lower boundery 95% confidence interval AUC ROC. *_train_ROCAUC_upper95CI - upper boundery 95% confidence interval AUC ROC. *_train_Accuracy - accuracy training set. *_train_Sensitivity - sensitivity training set. *_train_Specificity - sensitivity training set. logic, every parameter also calculated testing (_test_) validation (_valid_) set. method generated probability, default cutoff used predictions. Let’s see general performance (accuracy) methods benchmark:  OmicSelector package, final optimal feature signature can selected 3 ways: 1. Picking signature achieved best accuracy training, testing validation: (metaindex = mean 3 accuracy metrics) 2. Picking signature achieved best accuracy testing validation: (metaindex = mean 2 accuracy metrics) 3. signature achieved best sensitivity specificity validation: (metaindex = mean sensitivity specificity validation dataset) good practice assess learning performance considered signatures across different classification methods. , visualize /underfitting selected methods comparing accuracy score testing validation sets 3 top scoring signatures across selection model architectures.  relationship betweend accuracy testing validation sets can also pictured scatterplot:
code:

= melt(acc2, id.vars = "method") %>%     filter(variable != "metaindex") %>%     filter(variable != "miRy") accmelt = cbind(accmelt, strsplit2(accmelt$variable, "_")) acctest = accmelt$value[accmelt$`2` == "test"] accvalid = accmelt$value[accmelt$`2` == "valid"] accmeth = accmelt$method[accmelt$`2` == "test"] unique(accmeth) #> [1] "sigtop"           "topFC"            "sigtopSMOTE"      #> [4] "cfs_sig"          "fcsig"            "my_own_signature" plot5 = ggplot(, aes(x = as.numeric(acctest), y = as.numeric(accvalid), shape = accmeth)) + geom_point() + scale_x_continuous(name = "Accuracy on test set",     limits = c(0.5, 1)) + scale_y_continuous(name = "Accuracy on validation set", limits = c(0.5, 1)) + theme_bw() grid.arrange(arrangeGrob(plot5, ncol = 1, nrow = 1))

"))     par(mfrow = c(1, 2))     acc = OmicSelector_best_signature_proposals_meta11("benchmark.csv")     metody = OmicSelector_get_benchmark_methods("benchmark.csv")     ktory_set = match(acc$method[i], OmicSelector_get_benchmark("benchmark.csv")$method)     # do_ktorej_kolumny = which(colnames(acc) == 'metaindex') barplot(as.numeric(acc[i,1:do_ktorej_kolumny]))     for (ii in 1:length(metody)) {          temp = OmicSelector_get_benchmark("benchmark.csv") %>%             dplyr::select(starts_with(paste0(metody[ii], "_t")), starts_with(paste0(metody[ii], "_v")))          ROCtext = paste0("Training AUC ROC: ", round(temp[ktory_set, 1], 2), " (95%CI: ", round(temp[ktory_set, 2], 2), "-", round(temp[ktory_set, 3],             2), ")")          temp = temp[, -c(1:3)]         temp2 = as.numeric(temp[ktory_set, ])         temp3 = matrix(temp2, nrow = 3, byrow = T)         colnames(temp3) = c("Accuracy", "Sensitivity", "Specificity")         rownames(temp3) = c("Training", "Testing", "Validation")         temp3 = t(temp3)          plot1 = barplot(temp3, beside = T, ylim = c(0, 1), xlab = paste0(ROCtext, "
Black - accuracy, blue - sensitivity, green - specificity"), width = 0.85,             col = c("black", "blue", "green"), legend = F, args.legend = list(x = "topright", bty = "n", inset = c(0, -0.25)), cex.lab = 0.7, main = paste0(acc$method[i],                 " - ", metody[ii]), font.lab = 2)         ## Add text at top of bars         text(x = plot1, y = as.numeric(temp3), label = paste0(round(as.numeric(temp[ktory_set, ]) * 100, 1), "%"), pos = 3, cex = 0.6, col = "red")     }     par(mfrow = c(1, 1))  } #>  #>  #> ## sigtop #>  #>  #> ## topFC #>  #>  #> ## sigtopSMOTE overlap = OmicSelector_signature_overlap(acc$method[1:3], "benchmark.csv") attr(overlap, "intersections") #> $sigtopSMOTE #> [1] "hsa.miR.199a.3p" #>  #> $`sigtop:topFC` #> [1] "hsa.miR.199b.5p" #>  #> $`sigtop:sigtopSMOTE` #> [1] "hsa.miR.30e.3p"   "hsa.miR.132.3p"   "hsa.miR.30c.2.3p" #> [4] "hsa.miR.199a.5p"  "hsa.miR.338.3p"   "hsa.miR.139.5p"   #>  #> $`sigtop:topFC:sigtopSMOTE` #> [1] "hsa.miR.21.5p"  "hsa.miR.30a.3p" "hsa.miR.217.5p" "hsa.miR.375.3p" #>  #> $topFC #> [1] "hsa.miR.192.5p"  "hsa.miR.194.5p"  "hsa.miR.429"     #> [4] "hsa.miR.141.3p"  "hsa.miR.200a.3p" "hsa.miR.708.3p" OmicSelector_vulcano_plot(selected_miRNAs = de$miR, DE = de, only_label = selected_miRNAs) OmicSelector_heatmap(x = dplyr::select(mixed, selected_miRNAs), rlab = data.frame(Class = mixed$Class, Mix = mixed$mix), zscore = F, margins = c(10, 10)) OmicSelector_heatmap(x = dplyr::select(mixed, selected_miRNAs), rlab = data.frame(Class = mixed$Class, Mix = mixed$mix), zscore = T, margins = c(10, 10)) cat(paste0(gsub("\.", "-", selected_miRNAs), collapse = ", ")) #> hsa-miR-21-5p, hsa-miR-30e-3p, hsa-miR-30a-3p, hsa-miR-217-5p, hsa-miR-132-3p, hsa-miR-30c-2-3p, hsa-miR-199a-5p, hsa-miR-375-3p, hsa-miR-338-3p, hsa-miR-139-5p, hsa-miR-199b-5p

e1071_1.7-9          haven_2.5.0          #> [151] reshape2_1.4.4       gtable_0.3.0 packageDescription("OmicSelector") #> Package: OmicSelector #> Type: Package #> Title: OmicSelector - a package for biomarker selection based on #>        high-throughput experiments. #> Version: 1.0.0 #> Author: Konrad Stawiski #> Maintainer: Konrad Stawiski <konrad.stawiski@umed.lodz.pl> #> Description: OmicSelector is package is the environment, #>        docker-based application and R package for biomarker #>        signature selection from high-throughput experiments. #>        Initially developed for miRNA-seq. The package introduces #>        automatic and structured feature selection with further #>        benchmarking using multiple data mining methods, thus #>        allow to find the most overfitting resiliant signature #>        (set of featrues) that can be used in biomarker validation #>        studies. E.g. this package can be used to find the set of #>        miRNAs with the greatest biomarker potential based on #>        miRNAs-seq. This set can be further validated in cheaper #>        qPCR studies. #> License: License: MIT + file LICENSE #> Encoding: UTF-8 #> LazyData: true #> Suggests: knitr, rmarkdown #> VignetteBuilder: what: OmicSelector - a package for biomarker selection based on high-throughput experiments.
title: OmicSelector - a package for biomarker selection based on high-throughput experiments.
text: OmicSelector environment, docker-based application R package biomarker signiture selection (feature selection) & deep learning diagnostic tool development high-throughput high-throughput omics experiments multidimensional datasets. initially developed miRNA-seq (small RNA, smRNA-seq; hence previous name miRNAselector), RNA-seq qPCR, can applied every problem numeric features selected counteract overfitting models. Using tool, can choose features, like miRNAs, significant diagnostic potential (based results miRNA-seq, validation qPCR experiments). can also develop best deep learning model signature, well IDE complex data mining project (contains R Studio, Jupyter notebooks VS Code.. integrated one!).  primary purpose OmicSelector provide set candidate features (biomarkers) validation biomarker study , e.g., high-throughput experiments. package performs feature selection first. next step, sets features tested process called “benchmarking”. benchmarking, try biomarkers’ sets using various data-mining (machine learning) methods. Based average performance groups cross-validation holdout-validation (testing test set /validation set), can suggest signatures (set features) tremendous potential validation. feautres selected, OmicSelector can perform advanced modeling deep feedforward neural networks without autoencoders. best network developed using comperhensive grid search optimal hyperparameters. section works Tensorflow (via Keras), computations can GPU-accelerated! best network can easily implemented clinical practice using interactive application.

title: OmicSelector_OmicSelector — OmicSelector_OmicSelector
text: Main function package. aim function perform feature selection using multiple methods create formulas benchmarking. loads data working directory. output mainly created files working directory. Log temporary files placed created `temp` subfolder. package offers 60 feature selection methods. methods check function defined `m` parameter. Pearls methods:

title: OmicSelector_OmicSelector — OmicSelector_OmicSelector
code: OmicSelector_OmicSelector(   wd = getwd(),   m = c(1:70),   max_iterations = 10,   code_path = system.file("extdata", "", package = "OmicSelector"),   register_parallel = T,   clx = NULL,   stamp = as.numeric(Sys.time()),   prefer_no_features = 11,   conda_path = "/home/konrad/anaconda3/bin/conda",   debug = F,   timeout_sec = 172800,   type = "auto" )

title: OmicSelector_OmicSelector — OmicSelector_OmicSelector
text: wd Working directory data (`mixed_train.csv`, `mixed_test.csv` `mixed_validation.csv` created `OmicSelector_prepare_split` present). m Methods feature selection performed. vector integers minimum 1 maximum 70. definition numbers please see vignette. max_iterations Maximum number iterations selected methods. Setting high may results long comupting time. code_path folder python external scripts placed (especially WxNet method). default additional code provided package. register_parallel use parallel processing speed computing time. Seting FALSE may aid debuging. clx parameter may used passing already register computing cluster (created registered `doParallel` tools). may lower computing time saving time register new cluster. stamp character vector timestamp used marking output files. prefer_no_features Maximum number miRNAs can selected tools method allows . conda_path Patch "conda" bindary used executing python scripts. debug Gives additional debug information (saves .rdata feature selection completed, prints formulas log) timeout_sec Timeout method terminated finished. may useful keep long methods limited, wait ethernity results. type Parameter 'mode' forwarded OmicSelector_differential_expression_ttest essential many feature selection methods. Note 'var_type.txt' file exists working directory superior value set directly function - designed GUI. Please refer OmicSelector_differential_expression_ttest manual understand 'mode' worOmicSelector_

title: OmicSelector_OmicSelector — OmicSelector_OmicSelector
text: list selected formulas. Note , due purpose package `OmicSelector_merge_formulas` may better option get output processes run function.

title: OmicSelector_OmicSelector — OmicSelector_OmicSelector
text: - Sig = miRNAs p-value <0.05 BH correction (DE using t-test) - Fcsig = sig + absolute log2FC filter (included abs. log2FC>1) - Cfs = Correlation-based Feature Selection Machine Learning (: https://www.cs.waikato.ac.nz/~mhall/thesis.pdf) - Classloop = Classification using different classification algorithms (classifiers) embedded feature selection using different schemes performance validation (: https://rdrr.io/cran/Biocomb/man/classifier.loop.html) - Fcfs = CFS algorithm forward search (https://rdrr.io/cran/Biocomb/man/select.forward.Corr.html) - MDL methods = minimal description length (MDL) discretization algorithm different method feature ranking feature selection (AUC, SU, CorrSF) (: https://rdrr.io/cran/Biocomb/man/select.process.html) - bounceR = genetic algorithm componentwise boosting (: https://www.statworx.com/ch/blog/automated-feature-selection-using-bouncer/) - RandomForestRFE = recursive feature elimination using random forest resampling assess performance. (: https://topepo.github.io/caret/recursive-feature-elimination.html#resampling--external-validation) - GeneticAlgorithmRF (: https://topepo.github.io/caret/feature-selection-using-genetic-algorithms.html) - SimulatedAnnealing =  makes small random changes (.e. perturbations) initial candidate solution (: https://topepo.github.io/caret/feature-selection-using-simulated-annealing.html) - Boruta (: https://www.jstatsoft.org/article/view/v036i11/v36i11.pdf) - spFSR = simultaneous perturbation stochastic approximation (SPSA-FSR) (: https://arxiv.org/abs/1804.05589) - varSelRF = using --bag error minimization criterion, carry variable elimination random forest, successively eliminating least important variables (importance returned random forest). (: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16398926) - WxNet = neural network-based feature selection algorithm transcriptomic data (: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6642261/) - Step = backward stepwise method feature selection based logistic regression (GLM, family = binomial) using AIC criteria (stepAIC) functions .stepwise package (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/.stepwise/index.html) detailed defitions please see tutorial vignette.

title: OmicSelector_benchmark — OmicSelector_benchmark
text: Second important function package. Using formulas selected `OmicSelector_OmicSelector` function, test derived miRNA sets systematic manner using multiple model induction methods. function allows benchmark miRNA sets context potential diagnostic test creation. Hidden feature package application `mxnet`. Note `mxnet` installed configured seperatly.

title: OmicSelector_benchmark — OmicSelector_benchmark
code: OmicSelector_benchmark(   wd = getwd(),   search_iters = 2000,   keras_epochs = 5000,   keras_threads = floor(parallel::detectCores()/2),   search_iters_mxnet = 5000,   cores = detectCores() - 1,   input_formulas = readRDS("featureselection_formulas_final.RDS"),   output_file = "benchmark.csv",   algorithms = c("mlp", "mlpML", "svmRadial", "svmLinear", "rf", "C5.0", "rpart",     "rpart2", "ctree"),   holdout = T,   stamp = as.character(as.numeric(Sys.time())),   OmicSelector_docker = F )

title: OmicSelector_benchmark — OmicSelector_benchmark
text: wd Working directory `OmicSelector_OmicSelector` also working. search_iters number random hyperparameters tested process model induction. keras_epochs Number epochs used keras-based methods, keras methods used. (e.g. "mlpKerasDropout", "mlpKerasDecay") cores Number cores using parallel processing. output_file csv file benchmark. algorithms Caret methods checked benchmark processing. default logistic regression always included. holdout Best set hyperparameters can selected using: (1) TURE - using hold-validation test set, (2) FALSE - using 10-fold cross-validation repeated 5 times. stamp Character vector timestamp make benchmark unique. OmicSelector_docker Adding features used OmicSelector GUI. Almost always set FALSE (default). input_fomulas List formulas created `OmicSelector_OmicSelector` `OmicSelector_merge_formulas`. formulas check benchmark. gpu Wheter use GPU mxnet keras processing. Default: F keras_threds package supports training keras networks parallel. can set number threads used. (e.g. "mlpKerasDropout", "mlpKerasDecay")

title: OmicSelector_differential_expression_ttest — OmicSelector_differential_expression_ttest
text: variable performes standard differential expression analysis using unpaired t-test BH Bonferonni correction. requires `ttpm_features` object, e.g. matrix log-transformed TPM-normalized miRNAs counts miRNAs placed `ttpm` design (.e. columns cases placed rows). Classess passed `classes` vector length equal number rows `ttpm_polfiltrze` contain "Case" "Control" labels!! function returns miRNAs sorted BH-corrected p-value.

text: ttpm_features matrix log-transformed TPM-normalized miRNAs counts feature matrix miRNAs/features placed `ttpm` design (.e. columns cases placed rows) classes vector describing label case. contain "Case" "Control" labeles!!!! mode use 'logtpm' log(TPM) data 'deltact' qPCR deltaCt values. parameters sets fold-change calculated. Setting "auto" try read settings var_type.txt (used docker).

title: OmicSelector_load_datamix — OmicSelector_load_datamix
text: function loads data created preparation phase. requires output constructed `OmicSelector_prepare_split` function placed working directory (`wd`), thus files `mixed_train.csv`, `mixed_test.csv` `mixed_valid.csv` exist directory. imbalanced data, fuction can perform balancing using: 1. ROSE: https://journal.r-project.org/archive/2014/RJ-2014-008/RJ-2014-008.pdf - default generate 10 * number cases orginal dataset. 2. SMOTE (default): https://arxiv.org/abs/1106.1813 - defult use `perc.=100` `k=10`.

title: OmicSelector_load_datamix — OmicSelector_load_datamix
code: OmicSelector_load_datamix(   wd = getwd(),   smote_easy = T,   smote_over = 200,   use_smote_not_rose = T,   replace_smote = F,   selected_miRNAs = NULL,   class_interest = "Case",   remove_zero_var = T )

title: OmicSelector_load_datamix — OmicSelector_load_datamix
text: wd Working directory files loading. smote_easy Easy SMOTE (just SMOTE minority cases amount difference minority majority classes). set TRUE smote_over meaning. Please undersampling majority class performed method, consider best small datasets. smote_over Oversampling minority class SMOTE function (deterimes number cases final dataset). See `perc.` `DMwR::SMOTE()`` function. use_smote_not_rose Set TRUE SMOTE instead ROSE. replace_smote analyses may want replace imbalanced train dataset balanced dataset. saved coding time functions. selected_miRNAs null - take features staring "hsa", set - vector feature names selected. class_interest Value variable "Class" used cases interest. Default: "Case". values variable Class used controls encoded "Control". remove_zero_var Remove features zero variance.
